explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required to check for dead code in OS_CondVarGetInfo:

- OS_CHECK_POINTER: This macro governs the early parameter check/behaviour when condvar_prop is NULL (e.g. returns an error or aborts). Understanding its effect is necessary to know whether the function can continue and whether subsequent code may be dead in some builds/configurations.

- OS_condvar_prop_t: The definition (layout and fields, especially the size and name field) is required to assess whether the memset and subsequent strncpy/copies are redundant or necessary (initialization vs assignment), and whether removing them would change behaviour.

- memset: The standard-library call zeroes the output structure before other assignments. To decide if that initialization is dead, one must know exactly what memset does here and whether any later code (including Impl) overwrites all fields.

- strncpy: The copy of name_entry into condvar_prop->name could be the only place writing a terminator/bytes; its semantics (possible truncation/no-terminator) interact with the earlier memset. To judge if the memset or this strncpy is dead requires knowing strncpy semantics and buffer sizes.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: This call controls the conditional that guards almost all work in the function (returns OS_SUCCESS or an error). Its behaviour (when it can return success, whether it sets the token) determines whether the guarded block is ever executed and thus whether the guarded operations are dead under some circumstances.

- OS_SUCCESS: The return-code constant used in the conditional; needed to interpret OS_ObjectIdGetById results and determine which branch executes.

- OS_object_token_t: The token type (by-value or struct layout) and whether OS_ObjectIdGetById initializes it are necessary to reason about passing &token into OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl and OS_ObjectIdRelease — i.e., whether those calls are meaningful or redundant.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: The macro (or accessor) used to obtain record from the global table; needed to know whether it has side effects and whether the record pointer can be NULL or stale, which affects whether subsequent dereferences are necessary or redundant.

- OS_global_condvar_table: The global table symbol underlying OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its structure/content determines what record->name_entry and record->creator actually are and whether obtaining the record is necessary for correct behaviour.

- OS_common_record_t: The record structure and the fields name_entry and creator are read into condvar_prop. Knowing whether those reads are the sole source of those fields or are redundant with what OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl does is required to decide if they are dead.

- OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl: This backend implementation may modify condvar_prop or return_code, possibly overwriting earlier assignments (memset, strncpy, creator assignment). To determine whether the prior operations are dead (i.e., could be removed without changing behaviour), the Impl behaviour must be known.

- OS_ObjectIdRelease: Releases the token; removing it could change resource lifetime/behaviour (leaks, synchronization). To determine whether that release is dead (has no observable effect), you must know what it does and how OS_ObjectIdGetById/transaction semantics work.

Together these symbols let the analyst decide whether initializations and field assignments performed in OS_CondVarGetInfo are actually required for correct observable behaviour, or whether some are dead code.
